prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 100453
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are targeting a sample of 10 protoplanetary disks around A-type stars (Herbig AeBe). The maximum size of our targets is < 4'' and we need 1 pointing per target with the 12m array. We request the longest array configuration which gives us an angular resolution of ~ 0.2'', which corresponds to a linear resolution of 20-30 AU at the distance of our targets. The spectral setup includes the four molecular transitions needed to fulfill our science case plus a continuum band (low resolution). With the sensitivity limit requested here we will be able to detect a total gas mass reservoir down to one Saturn mass. We have created 10 identical Science Goals, one for each science targets. Note that we tried to combine more targets in one science goal to share the calibrations (and save telescope time), however, the duration of the science observation (on-source + overheads) is longer than 50 minutes for 2 targets and a second calibrator is needed. This is why we created 10 different SGs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: All the data requested here are needed to fulfill our primary science objectives. Observations of the J=2-1 line of the 3 CO isotopologues is fundamental to measure the gas surface density and to account for CO selective photodissociation (see Scientific Justification). The DCO+ J=3-2 transition is needed to determine the position of the CO sublimation front. Finally, the continuum bandpass is needed to measure the dust surface density profile. The resolution of 0.2 km/s is needed to study the gas dynamics in the outer disk (low keplerian velocity). The angular resolution of 0.2" is fundamental to resolve a linear scale of 20-30 AU and so to study the outer disk structure. Our sensitivity limit (5 mJy/beam) is dictated by our need to detect faint C18O and DCO+ emission in the outer part of the protoplanetary disk. Note that because of the decrease in sensitivity at the edges of the sidebands, we will have a sligthly lower sensitivity for the 13CO and 12CO lines. This is not an issue for us as the 12CO and 13CO lines are expected to be brighter than the C18O and DCO+ lines. The resolution of 0.2 km/s is needed to study the gas dynamics in the outer disk (low keplerian velocity). The 5 mJy/beam limit is based on the ALMA science verification data of a similar target (HD 163296) and on our model estimates. In the case of the science verification ALMA images of HD 163296, the r.m.s. of C18O (J=3-2) is 0.03 Jy.km/s/beam which is not sufficient to detect the faint emission in the outer part of the disk (see Fig.2 of scientific justification). The sensitivity proposed here is needed to detect the faint C18O and DCO+ emission down to a 4 sigma level of 20mJy.km/s which allows us to easily detect a total gas mass of one Saturn mass (based on our model results).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a comprehensive program to determine the structure of the outer region (> 20 AU) of protoplanetary disks around young A-type stars. The primary goal is to measure the gas and dust surface density structure. In turn, this will provide the radial variation of the gas-to-dust ratio as well as the total gas mass. This information is fundamental to understand the initial conditions of gas giant planet formation and make the link with directly imaged exoplanets around A-type stars. Despite its importance, we still do not know the total amount of the gas reservoir available to form planets in disks. Thanks to ALMA we can now use the faint, optically thin, emission of the rare CO isotopologues to address the gas reservoir and its radial distribution. We have selected a sample of nearby, isolated disks for which we have collected a large multi-wavelength data set that will complement the ALMA images. This program will have a legacy value for the whole community providing a unique benchmark for detailed disk modelling.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: SRON Utrecht, SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
